utterances: It's not binding the way that the Kyoto Protocol is on its signatories.
It's a pledge and review.
You raise your right hand, I promise I'm going to do reduce my emissions and greenhouse gases but you can't hold me to it.
So, what happens at Cancun?
Do they expect to pick up where Copenhagen left off?
They would like to.
Now, everybody's keeping hopes very, very low.
No promises, because Copenhagen was such a disaster, they can't afford another one because they'll lose all credibility in the U.N.
process.
So, it kind of breaks into two processes.
One is that the Copenhagen countries, the big economies like the U.S.
and India and China, that are not part of the Kyoto Protocol, they'll go on their own direction.
They'll cut deals with each other on how much they'll need to cut their emissions in order to meet their targets and try to slow global warning.
The U.N.
will continue, even without a new treaty to replace Kyoto, trying to find whatever it can do, particularly with the developing world.
They're very concerned about developing countries, how they're going to be hit by climate change, will they have the technology to deal with it.
So, there's a lot of talk about funding mechanisms to take money from the rich countries and give it to the poor countries so that they can deal with this.
So, that seems to be more along the lines of what the United Nations is trying to do.
In the end, though, will any of it be enough to keep the planet from overheating?
I would love to say yes to that.
I would really like to say yes to that, but I can't.
The latest numbers - let's just take a look at the Copenhagen agreement again.
These are the big countries that emit lots of CO2, lots of greenhouse gases.
The pledges that they've come up with so far is not going to get us there.
It'll get us sort of close but they're not nearly stringent enough to keep the temperature of the earth going up, according to the scientific analysis at the moment.
The Kyoto Protocol itself is just scratching the surface.
I mean, the European countries have reduced their emissions somewhat, in part because of their economies since 1990.
Many of them went down the tubes.
So, they were not emitting very much.
Their industry was down.
So, I'd have to say this is just a single page in this very long book that's going to be climate change for the rest of this century.
NPR science correspondent Christopher Joyce.
Thanks a lot, Christopher.
My pleasure to be here.
Say I-95, and millions of Americans immediately get an image - if only red tail lights winking into your family's car on a crowded commute home.
For many, I-95 calls up happy recollections of the road you hit for a long haul to the beach and back.
All along the eastern seaboard, Interstate 95 has helped shape the daily lives and vacation dreams of the roughly 100 million people who reside alongside it.
They live in dense cities and rural counties in the 15 states through which I-95 passes on its north-south path.
The traffic peaks in August.
So beginning today, continuing for the next two weekends, NPR will take a closer look at this great river of traffic in a series we're calling ""I-95: The Road Most Traveled.
NPR's senior business editor, Marilyn Geewax, is here to tell us more.
Marilyn, thanks for being with us.
Hi, Scott.
I-95 has been around a long time.
So why a series?
Scott, I happened to see this article that was saying after all these years and years of delay, construction's finally going to start in September on this part that's called the missing link of I-95.
It's a short stretch where I-95 was never completed around Trenton, New Jersey.
And in theory, I-95 should be this unbroken highway that goes from Maine all the way down to Miami.
But its not; it's got this gap.
So we're going to talk about that missing link in a piece that's coming up in just a few moments.
And what makes I-95 distinctive compared with other interstates around the country?
Well, it's really a key transportation link for the whole East Coast, and this is the most densely populated part of the country, and it's also sort of the most historic.
The original 13 colonies are included on this road, and it passes through more states than any other interstate in the country.
(Spanish spoken).
I used to be a diehard stay until Katrina - never left 'til Katrina.
You know, this time you didn't have to tell me twice.
And I've heard that over and over again.
People I talk to say they stayed here; it was not a pleasant time.
They're all taking the mayor's advice, taking Governor Bobby Jindal's advice and getting out of town as quickly as possible.
So, this is something that residents here seemed to have gotten the message on.
They've learned their lesson and they're leaving.
If you had to sum up the mood in a word, Greg, would you say that people are stoic or panicky or resigned?
What would you say?
I would not say there's really much panic.
People are just taking this very business-like.
It does not seem like New Orleans, to be honest.
It's such a world away from what we saw during Katrina three years ago - being done very business-like, very methodically.
Even people who don't have their own way out of town, they're just doing this in a way that is just by the book.
NPR's Greg Allen from New Orleans.
Thanks very much.
We'll be watching it.
Thank you, Jacki.
In less than 24 hours, people will head to the polls in North Carolina and Indiana, and the Democratic presidential candidates are furiously courting voters and superdelegates.
In North Carolina, Senator Barack Obama has consistently held a lead over Senator Hillary Clinton.
But in Indiana, surveys indicate the race is much tighter.
Indiana's primary is open to Republicans and independents as well as Democrats.
I spoke with Indiana political analyst Brian Howey about the shape of the race there.
He says things in Indiana have been shifting.
Well, I certainly got the feeling that the momentum had shifted to Senator Clinton last week.
And then about mid-week, we had Representative Baron Hill followed by Joe Andrew the next day came out and endorsed Obama.
With Andrew, the former Democratic national chairman, that was a switch.
And what that did, I don't think that will draw a lot of new voters to Obama.
But what it did was change the subject, and he certainly needed to change the subject from Reverend Wright.
And since then, we've really the seen the gas-tax story take front stage center, and that may be the issue that decides this particular primary.
Now, both candidates have very different prescriptions for providing relief at the pump, who is actually gained more attraction on that issue?
Well, again looking at the latest Zogby tracking that had Obama up by two.
There's the Suffolk poll that has Clinton up by seven.
But I got the sense that the momentum on that issue certainly was shifting towards Obama and, yet, the Clinton people are very confident.
They think that they're going to do well here.
And I think it remains to be seen.
The wild card is we've got 200,000 new voters in this state.
There's no history to how they'll vote.
And so, there're all sorts of little interesting jigsaw pieces floating around and I don't think anybody can really say they've got the puzzle put together right now.
So, those 200,000 new voters you say are the wild card.
One of the interesting things about this contest is the way that both candidates, both Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama are going out of their way to court Republicans?
Well, we've seen a spectacle of Bill Clinton campaigning in Dan Burton's Congressional District, the 5th Congressional District.
And Burton was a thorn in his side throughout the eight years of the first Clinton presidency.
And it's very conservative - it's one of the most conservative Republican districts in the nation.
And here was Bill Clinton in places like Carmel, Indiana and Hartford City.
This past weekend he was up in northeastern Indiana, places like Cannonville and Angola, very Republican areas.
And we saw Barack Obama do a family picnic Novelsville and Hamilton County is again another extremely Republican area.

Like many states, Indiana has very big regional differences from top to bottom, how does that change the game in this election - if you take the top of the state and look at Lakeview County, near Illinois, and the center of the state near Indianapolis and Bloomington, and then Southern Indiana as you head toward Kentucky which is altogether different from the top, let's say?
Yes, you know, the Southern Indiana counties have a Kentucky feel to them and then you go up to Lake and Porter County and you're in Chicago.
I mean it's just an extension of Chicago.
You know, I've got this election as a tossup right now.
Things seem to tighten up in Lake County which should be - that's Obama's backyard - and apparently he made a big Chicago TV by which tells me that they've got concerns there.
I talked to Congressman Joe Donnelly from the Notre Dame, South Bend area.
He thinks his district - the 2nd Congressional District - is a tossup.
I've heard similar things in the Fort Wayne area.
That's the third congressional district.
Down in Southern Indiana, we had Lee Hamilton, literally barnstorming like he was running himself.
He hit, I think, eight different communities, and while that's Clinton country, when Lee Hamilton has something to say, those folks down there listen.
And Lee Hamilton there is barnstorming for Barack Obama?
Yes, absolutely.
He introduced Barack Obama at the Jefferson-Jackson Day Dinner.

And depending on where you are seated in the room, I saw one press report out of Fort Wayne saying that the crowd was definitely Obama, and yet where I was sitting at seem like it had a Clinton tilt to it.
So even, you know, something like 2,000 people gathered in a room, you got different opinions as to where things are stacking up.
Brian Howey, thank you so much.
Good to talk to you again.
Thanks, Michele.
Brian Howey is a political analyst and he's the editor of Howey Politics Indiana.
(SOUNDBITE OF A CAMPAIGN AD)
Its morning again in America.
Today, more men and women will go to work than ever before in our country's history.
That ad for Ronald Reagan's reelection campaign in 1984 was made by a master of television advertising, Hal Riney.
It features his signature soft-sell and his own voice in the narration laid-back and comforting.
(SOUNDBITE OF CAMPAIGN AD)
Its morning again in America.
And under the leadership of President Reagan, our country is prouder and stronger and better.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
That political vacuum is one that Kagame mostly created.
It also makes him the hardest to unseat.
Gregory Warner, NPR News, Nairobi.
This week, India made headlines when the nation put a spacecraft into orbit around Mars.
It's the first country to do it on the first try.
But today we turn to a different Indian fascination with celestial bodies.
From New Delhi NPR's Julie McCarthy reports on the role astrology plays in the day-to-day lives of Indians, including its scientists.
Astrology is the study of human destiny.
Is it superstition or is it science?
Neither says one leading practitioner who declares astrology a super science.
K.N.
RAO: Not an ordinary science, because it is extraterrestrial extra-physical, it is super physical, therefore supernormal, right?
